content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: cool challenge for a clash of code

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool game ;)
Can anyone check with other languages than python like C++/Java for this one? I didn't use S in my code so let me know if the length of the tasks is wrong
IMO there should be an input for the number of tasks

'1 worker can only work on 1 task at a time, and only 1 worker is permitted to work on 1 task. Every worker must finish their task before moving on to the next one.'

If I understand this part of the  description correctly an alternative that seems to encapsulate it's essence you may want to consider to clarify the description could be similar to

'A task must be assigned to a single worker. That worker must complete the task before being available for re-assignment to an awaiting task.'

A pet hate of mine: "amount of workers" should be "number of workers"
(use "amount" for things that cannot be counted, like sand, time or bravery)

> "the total time to finish all tasks in order"
Actually the tasks are not *finished* in order, they are attributed and started in order.
For instance:
2
2 1 1
The optimal time is 2, the task 2 finishes before the task 1.

Also it should be explicitly mentioned that we're looking for the minimum/optimal total time (we can guess it, but it should be written).

You should explicitly give the number of tasks in the input and improve the stub accordingly (to parse the list of tasks). It doesn't matter much in Python, but would help greatly in many languages.

As already said below, you should avoid numbers that do not fit in 64-bit ints.

I disagree with numbers like 23451111111352575472578246341465387 : the only effect of such numbers is to disallow usage of C/C++ languages when big numbers need a specific library, and has no effect with python. Furthermore, such values can't be a "real" value of a construction time, even with a small unit of time (µs). A constraint should be set  with maximum task time e.g. 1 <= time of a task <= 100000

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it works
Than you all for the replies! I will edit ASAP. If you have any other suggestions please let me know :)
Simple but I spend a long time dealing with the floats, you will be approved if you make them ints instead
Nice one, just correct what BeardedWhale said down below and maybe make some trickier test cases because in case of 1,2,3 workers, solution is pretty self explanatory looking at the input.

Good idea, but it should be clear what format is expected for the output (i.e. how many decimal places). Alternatively, make it all about integers, that would put more focus on the actual problem at hand.
Thank you! I made all floats into integers. Also to prevent people from looping and add time by 1 everytime, I made a heavy test case. Thanks for replying!
Thank you!

This is really coding games fault for having such sensitive output and no way to change it, but it's not trivial for languages that use printf (c++, haskell) to get the '2 decimal places but no trailing zeros' idea correct. As far as I know, please correct me if there is a nice way with printf
Thank you!

If you really want to use big values, please consider using  9223372036854775807 (2^63 - 1) as a maximum for your "output" to have a solution that works for(almost) every language. But I think that ~100000 for an input is a good value.
I have the code for minimum algorithm to find the best order, but it is way too hard to finish in 15 minutes. And thank you for letting me know to add the length!
Thanks, I fixed it!
Wow, I am bad at English so sorry and thank you! I will change it!
Yes you are right. I added that
the tasks line is read as a single string that's not even quite the right size, I'd say it would be better to read them as an array

No, I know...

What I'm saying is that "finish all tasks in order" is unclear as it's not actually true. The tasks must be *assigned* in order, not actually finished.

And it's possible for instance to assign all the tasks (in order) to the first worker, then the total time will be the sum of the tasks and won't be optimal, that's why you should still mention that we're looking for the minimum/optimal time.
Ok, thank you! My solution works well on these numbers, but I don't know if other langs do. Thank you for letting me know.
I don't know C++ or haskell, but I made the output to be int. That makes the challenge easier.

Thanks, when I said ints I meant numbers under 2^31 though, so the new test cases you added means that this problem requires implementing bigint or using a bigint class in pretty much every language but python. If you want to prevent looping you could keep it under 2^63 and use longs but don't go beyond that
